DOC.HEAD: Most Lawmakers Support Bush, Some Criticize
Eds: New material, editing throughout to include critical comment.
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress in both parties today supported President Bush's assault against Panama's Manuel Antonio Noriega, although one Democrat said Bush should have consulted with allies in advance and another called him ``trigger-happy.'' ``I support the president's decision,'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said in a brief statement from Mexico City, where he was meeting with government officials. ``It was made necessary by the reckless actions of Gen. Noriega.'' ``I hope that the restoration of democracy to Panama will occur as soon as possible,'' Mitchell said. ``I deeply regret the loss of life which resulted.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., also offered his support. ``I think under the circumstances, the decision is justified,'' he said. Bush asked him for his support in a telephone call at about 10 p.m. Tuesday. ``When there is the engagement of U.S. forces in the field, it behooves all of us to giver that support,'' Foley told reporters. ``My immediate reaction is: at last,'' said Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. ``After the failed coup of October, the administration faced two choices _ stow its anti-Noriega rhetoric and leave itself to the whims of events, or take the initiative and intervene. The latter was the better choice.'' And Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said he hoped the rest of the world would take note of ``the unique circumstances'' that faced Bush. ``It is unfortunate that the United States has been required to take these steps in Panama'' when it is asking for restraint on the part of the Soviet Union and China, he said. ``I called to tell the president, `my compliments to the chef','' said Sen. Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee. ``The majority of the Senate will feel good by this turn of events,'' Helms predicted in a phone call he placed to The Associated Press. However, Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said Bush should not have sent U.S. soldiers into action in Panama without the support and aid of other Central American nations. ``Personally, unless very clear evidence emerges of a direct threat against the Panama Canal or against American people or installations, I would not have engaged in such unilateral or such go-it-alone action,'' said Pell. But Pell said he would support the administration until the attack aimed at unseating Noriega was completed, and he hoped for ``as few deaths as possible to soldiers.'' Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., issued a harshly critical statement, calling Bush's action ``a trigger-happy act of gunboat diplomacy that continues our mindless 100-year abuse of small Central American nations.'' Edwards, chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on the Constitution, said Bush had violated the provision which requires Congress' consent to go to war. ``There was no danger to our national security from this weak, small country, nor was the Panama Canal in real peril,'' he said. And Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., interviewed on Cable News Network, said, ``It seems to me that what the president is doing is trying to correct for his failure to back up the insurgent forces in the Panamanian Defense Forces back in October. And I think he was wrong on both occasions. He didn't provide sufficient support last time and he's doing overkill this time.'' Sen. Richard Lugar of Indiana, a senior Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee, called the action ``an overwhelming success because democracy has now been inaugurated and installed in Panama.'' ``The canal is safe, Americans are safe,'' Lugar said, adding that the operation was ``a very important moment in the presidency of George Bush. It is a time when the president asserted his own leadership and did so effectively.'' Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, endorsed Bush's decision and praised the action as a ``blow against the international drug trade.'' ``We need to see how it plays out,'' said Senate Republican Leader Robert Dole in a telephone interview with the AP. ``I would guess there would be widespread bipartisan support for the president.'' Bush ordered the U.S. troops to Panama City to apprehend Noriega and bring him to the United States to stand trial on drug-smuggling charges, said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. The move also was intended to protect American lives as well as the Panama Canal, he said. ``I think the president has done the right thing and I suspect he'll have pretty widespread support in Congress,'' Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash., said in an interview with Seattle-based KIRO-TV. White House officials said top congressional leaders had been briefed on the mission to seize Noriega by force. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on the Western Hemisphere, also was briefed about the operation. He said on ``CBS This Morning'' that members of Congress he had talked to ``are standing by President Bush on this decision.'' Gorton called Noriega and his followers ``simply lawless bandits who broke up a free election and are ruling as nothing more or less than a drug cartel, and have constantly escalated their provocations against Americans and the security of the (Panama) Canal.'' Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., called Noriega ``a murderous thug'' who should be brought to trial in the United States for drug-smuggling. Noriega has been indicted on narcotics smuggling charges by grand juries in Miami and Tampa, Fla. ``President Bush was requested to intervene with armed force by the duly elected president of Panama, President (Guillermo) Endara, whose administration was denied from taking office by Noriega's thugs after being elected,'' Wilson said in a statement his office delivered to the AP's Los Angeles bureau. Dole said he met with Endara and other elected Panamanian officials Dec. 10 and ``they were in effect pleading with us to do something'' about Noriega. Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., interviewed on WBBM-AM radio in Chicago, said, ``I'm satisfied and gratified that the operation is under way.'' After the earlier failed coup attempt in Panama, he said, ``We looked impotent; we looked like Lilliputians.''
